poem:
**Edenglassie Ascendant**

In the labyrinths of Brisbane—  
Magandjin, Meanjin,  
a novel stirs, turns  
eucalyptus whispers  
to echoes of ancestors.  
Lucashenko's hand,  
a bridge over past  
and present waters,  
sculpts Queensland's soul,  
layered, complex,  
each page a stone  
upon the riverbed  
of understanding.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Melissa Lucashenko wins $30,000 prize for novel that ‘elevates our understanding of Queensland’s soul’ Melissa Lucashenko’s historical novel Edenglassie, about the colonisation of Magandjin/Meanjin/Brisbane, has won the highest accolade at the Queensland literary awards, with the judges praising it as a work that “elevates our understanding of Queensland’s soul”. Related: Edenglassie by Melissa Lucashenko review – Miles Franklin winner slices open Australia’s past and present It’s the second time Lucashenko has taken out the $30,000". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Melissa Lucashenko wins $30,000 prize for novel that ‘elevates our understanding of Queensland’s soul’ Melissa Lucashenko’s historical novel Edenglassie, about the colonisation of Magandjin/Meanjin/Brisbane, has won the highest accolade at the Queensland literary awards, with the judges praising it as a work that “elevates our understanding of Queensland’s soul”. Related: Edenglassie by Melissa Lucashenko review – Miles Franklin winner slices open Australia’s past and present It’s the second time Lucashenko has taken out the $30,000
